There’s a view that women have less value as they age, while older men become more attractive. In particular, misogynist corners of the Internet, there is a myth that women hid "the wall" at 30 and just completely shrivel up 🙄. Love Island shows that the ridiculous idea that 30 is somehow old has filtered into the mainstream. If you think of the women in your lives, we all look pretty similar at 25, 30, and 35, not much changes! And even when we do change and age, SO WHAT, the patriarchy wants women to see aging as a personal failure, instead of a natural process, literal proof of a life lived. To see 30 as the Sword of Damocles, the absolute thing to fear. The women “hitting-the-wall-at-thirty” propaganda is, of course, a complete fairytale. It’s a lie propagated to comfort the bitter men. They want to scare women into settling for whatever relationship they are in in their 20s. To settle for less. They want women to think that they are less worthy in their 30s and 40s, which also just so happen to be the ages when they are growing in confidence, financial security, experience, and wisdom. At the same time, men like to convince themselves that they are much more worthy as they age, so of course it is totally fine and not creepy when they are 50 years old hitting on women in their 20s. As women age, they become more themselves and take up more space, and that terrifies some men. (This is part of my Love Island series, for much more, including daily analysis, check out my Patreon link in the bio) #loveisland #loveislanduk #loveisland2023 #loveislandmeme #Britishtv #feminist #feminism #misogyny #womensupportingwomen❤️ #smashthepatriarchy #femaleempowermentquotes #feministquotes #feminist #feminism #empoweringquotes #realitytv #agingwell #aginglikefinewine #turning30 #selflovejourney #agingwithattitude #agingdisgracefully #agingwell #agingredefined #turning30isntsobad #thirtysomething

Happy Women's History Month! Throughout history, women's discoveries, inventions and contributions have been underplayed or omitted entirely by the men who stole their credit as well as the men who wrote the history books. When you consider the barriers and oppression these women had to overcome to gain the education, resources, time and access to the equipment needed for these discoveries, these omissions are even more egregious. The idea of one man revolutionising history through his special genius is a false narrative, created by men who wish to paint themselves that way. The story of discoveries and intervention is more often than not one of teams, teams building on the work of people that have gone before them, teams that include women, and benefit from the labour and work of women. Also sometimes men just straight steal the work of women, they get away with it because the structural power is on their side. So let's give these incredible women to long overdue credit they deserve. (Even if we can't give them the Nobels they deserve) Source: The independent, Scoopwhoop, Feminism4everyone #herstory #womenshistory #historylovers #internationalwomensday #womeninhistory #iwd2023 #internationalwomensday2023 #womensupportingwomen❤️ #womensday #iwd #womensmonth #womenshistorymonth #womeninstem #womeninstemfields #intersectionalfeminism #internationalwomensday #intersectionalfeminist #womenshistorymonth #feministquotes #feminist #feminism #femaleempowerment #womeninleadership #womenshistorymonth #womensrights #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #empoweringwomen #feministaf #womensupportingwomen❤️ #socialjusticeeducation #womenshistorymonth2023 #historylovers #womenshistorymonth #girlpower💪 #historymeme

When I was growing up, I felt excluded from skateparks and football pitches and traditionally “male” outdoor areas. When my friends and I went to the skatepark, we were told to leave on multiple occasions by boys. After a while we just stopped showing up. A recent study by The Royal Institute of British Architects highlighted research that found 80 per cent of the people who use outdoor spaces and equipment for young people are male. Academics from the Department of Educational Studies at Goldsmiths university, gave evidence to the inquiry & said girls are not given the access to community spaces that boys are. And added that they feel they do not have a “right” to use skate parks, while often equipment is built with the “default male user” in mind, so the height of equipment is often set too high. I’m learning how to skate in my late 20’s, and even I find this is still the case. I’m trying to reclaim some of those spaces, and have been learning to skate for about a year and a half now. While things are definitely changing for the better, it seems they are not changing quickly enough. Public space, and recreational spaces should be equal and accessible to all. It’s incredibly sad that in 2024 girls STILL feel that they don’t have access or are able to be in these spaces. These studies are also rarely inclusive of the experiences of gender non conforming and trans kids, who surely have an even tougher barriers to accessing these spaces. The charity Make Space for Girls is trying to address and change this, but we need more investment funding and urgency into democratising and creating spaces that aren’t restricted by gender. #makespaceforwomen #makespacefortranspeople #makespaceforgirls #publicspaces #safespaces

If yesterday has highlighted anything, it’s the grim reality of how dangerous male entitlement can be. The root cause of this is misogyny. It’s patriarchy. It’s sexism repackaged as “being a better” or “real” man, by toxic social media influencers. It’s social media companies themselves allowing this content to be eaten up, unchallenged. It’s an entire society that turns a blind eye to the cause of violence towards women and girls. None of these problems are new, they have just repeatedly been left to fester, morph and grow until we are at a place where a high profile public figure can come on live Tv and make misogynistic remarks about a woman, and the next day lament the death of a 15 year old girl by a boy - and not see how those actions are connected. Misogyny breeds violence. It’s never just a comment, banter, a joke - it’s a culture that enables women to be seen as less than men. As disposable, without agency. We didn’t need to have this horrific wake up call. It shouldn’t take the violent death of a teenage girl for society to listen. Misogyny should be treated with the same severity as any other form of terror and violence. This isn’t something women should have to put up with anymore.

"I had just started working as an administrator for a car dealership. As you can imagine, it was 90% male and lad culture was rife. The daily remarks on my appearance ranged from run of the mill "compliments" e.g. you look nice to the graphic i.e. speculating about how I would be in bed, commenting on my figure in lewd detail, in short they began to wear thin very quickly. ⠀ One day, I was on my lunch break and stood outside in the staff car park which was in the back. I was on the phone to my boyfriend, pacing between two cars as we chatted and then I paused to rest. Out of nowhere, I felt an aggressive squeeze on my bum, I turned around and one of the drivers (who was weeks away from his retirement), just smiled and winked at me. I was so shocked that the only words I could seem to say were 'I'm on the phone to my boyfriend!'. He walked off to the garage without a word or an apology. I reported it to my line manager straight away, he told me this would get really ugly for me and advised me to let it go. His boss, who was on holiday when the incident took place, told me he had expected me to have a sense of humour about the whole thing and said 'don't be so dramatic.' I quit the next day" - Jayanna⠀ Thanks to @nukketdesigner who designed the gorgeous text 💖🎨. This shoot was done on FaceTime, and is part of a series collaborating with graphic designers and illustrators. If you would like to be photographed for the series, or are a designer who would like to collab, please get in touch.

In 2023, a year that has already brought to light so many horrific abuses of women and girls, we’ve now been served yet another reminder that there are still people out there who refuse to treat us with basic respect and dignity.⁠ ⁠ Following a now-viral on-air misogynistic rant, controversial GB News presenter and political ‘activist’ Laurence Fox has been formally suspended by the channel after he refused to apologise for asking “Who’d want to shag that?” about a female journalist live on air.⁠ ⁠ This kind of casual misogyny isn’t just repulsive playground talk. It’s seriously harmful to women’s safety, writes Stylist’s @amy.beecham. Why is it that “I wouldn’t sleep with you” is still considered the ultimate insult for women? Read more at the link in our bio.

"For most couples, date night is something to look forward to, but just over a year into my relationship with my ex-partner, the prospect filled me with dread. I knew that once we’d finished getting ready for a night out together, I’d be greeted by a sullen face and endless shaming comments about my fashion and beauty choices, which he insisted were designed to command attention from other men."⁠ ⁠ Jonah Hill and Darius Daulton Jackson have come under scrutiny for allegedly trying to control how their female partners present themselves. Brinta Ponnuthurai, known online as Brynta Ponn, has racked up more than 100,000 followers on Instagram thanks to her message of body confidence, but that self-esteem wasn’t always present. Growing up as a South Asian girl in Toronto, Canada, she faced judgment for her skin, which led to her experiencing “deep hatred and resentment” towards her appearance. ⁠ ⁠ Through a process of unlearning the toxic messages we’re told about our skin, practising gentleness and refusing to hide away, @bryntstagram worked her way from self-hatred to absolute self-love.⁠ ⁠ We chatted with the influencer about her journey to skin freedom. Link in bio.

Why are women expected to dress sexy while men aren't? Because how we understand "sexy" in our culture is all about the male gaze. In a patriarchal culture, failing to meet the male gaze, demonstrating sexual agency as a woman, and/or not conforming to a narrow set of beauty standards are all met with sexist backlash. Women's success under the patriarchy is tied to how fuckable they are. Woman can't simply opt out of this, no matter what choices individual women make about the way they dress or behave, women’s choices would still be limited by the desires of men. The way that women conduct themselves in a sexist society, even when problematic, is not worth critically analyzing without attention to the wider context of the patriarchical system we are trying to survive and thrive within. Our society values physical attractiveness, but our cultural construction of femininity places a premium on beauty and body size, as an integral aspect of what is valuable. Our society tends to be more forgiving toward men who deviate from dominant beauty standards of muscularity because there is less emphasis on the way he looks, and perhaps more so on how smart he is, how successful he is, or if he is a good 'breadwinner' for his family. "Dad bods" are seen a sign that a man is devoted to his family and his female partner. While "mom bods" are rarely truly represented in our media (though some incredible mums are using social media to change that). Mum's are pressured to 'snap back' after the physical trauma of birth and are seen as "lazy" and "unattractive" if they embrace their new body. Another week, another case of men publicly prescribing and shaming female sexuality. 💁‍♀️⠀ By now I’m sure most of you would have seen or heard about the single “WAP” by Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion, and probably the predictable backlash and distress it seems to have caused many cis straight men. Funny how when a man talks about and sexualises a woman, it’s ok, it’s hot, it’s what we are programmed to see. But when a woman starts owning and reclaiming her sexuality, her body, and shock horror... talking in a sexual way, It’s suddenly “shameless” and “disappointing on a personal and moral level.” - A direct quote from CeeLo Green. ⠀ Why do we hold women in the media and popular culture to different standards than men? And also who the fuck cares. I’m bored of the male gaze, and I’m wholly here for the roles reversing. ⠀ From Ben Shapiro citing misinformation about women’s hygiene to Russel Brand mansplaining feminism, it shows how we are still very much living to the double standards and pitfalls of the patriarchy. YAWN. 🥱⠀ #wap #stopsexualisingwomen #fuckthemalegaze #cardib #megantheestallion

Last week, the Angiolini inquiry’s report into the circumstances that led to Sarah Everard’s murder was published, concluding that Wayne Couzens “should never have been a police officer” as Everard’s family insisted that “Sarah died because he was a police officer – she would never have got into a stranger’s car”.⁠ ⁠ Now, the BBC’s new documentary Sarah Everard: The Search For Justice, made in close collaboration with the Everard family, delves deeper into the Met’s investigation into her murder, looking at how this devastating crime unfolded and the impact that was felt across the country.⁠ ⁠ At the link in bio, Stylist's @amy.beecham writes how the documentary, which airs tonight, is a harrowing but important reflection on the extent of violence against women and girls in our society.

According to domestic abuse charity Refuge, one in three UK women have experienced online abuse or harassment. Currently, the Online Safety Bill, which includes protections against cyberflashing and deepfakes, is on its way through parliament in a bid to change the murky laws around the way perpetrators can be prosecuted for digital crimes.⁠ ⁠ In her new BBC documentary Asking For It?, actor and comedian @emilyatack reveals her own experience of online sexual harassment, which ranges from explicit images to rape threats, all while wrestling with the harmful internal narrative that it’s somehow her fault. ⁠ ⁠ "I noticed, particularly in lockdown, that there was a huge rise in the amount of dick pics I was being sent,” she says. “My whole life I’ve kind of struggled with male behaviour towards me, but this was something even more intense. When I’m being sent videos and sexually violent language, I’m being sexually harassed every single day of my life, at home, with my phone in my hands.”⁠ ⁠ Read the interview, via the link in our bio.

On a historic night that should have been about what women can do – not what they look like – singer Becky Hill was the victim of body shaming trolls.⁠ ⁠ “I’m also sorry you think that what I was wearing devalued my talent and wanted me to be more covered up to be a role model for body confidence to young women. As you can read, that is an oxymoron,” she said.⁠ ⁠ Hill described her final show performance as “one of the biggest moments of my career,” adding that she will “remember that moment until the day I die”.⁠ ⁠ “It was an absolute honour to open up such an iconic and historic moment for women’s football, and perform in all my popstar glory.”⁠ ⁠ Read more at the link in our bio.

As someone who is 5' 8" I have experienced rejection from men due to my height plenty of times, I am have in the past wished I was shorter so more men would see me as dating potential. I have never been particularly bothered by men's height myself but when I have dated men a couple of inches shorter than me, I have noticed how odd people think it is. People make all kinds of judgements about relationships and people's gender roles based on people's height. I have certainly found myself doing a Princess Di and trying to shrink myself around men who are shorter than me. My current boyfriend is the same height as me and I think it's great being able to see eye to eye with no neck straining. Height preferences in dating is so common and so normalised (especially in heterosexual relationships), and like other preferences it's worth considering where it comes from: do you feel uncomfortablely big around men who are shorter than you, like you are taking up too much space or taking on a more masculine role? Do you see taller men as being more masculine or more of a protector or more of a man? No one is forcing anyone to dating someone they don't want to, it's just always worth in life considering where your desires come from and if they are really as innate as we tend to think they are. It feels weird posting this because 32 really isn't that old, but a 28 year old went viral on TikTok with a similar video where loads of teenagers were freaking out about ageing in the comments. When you are a woman, you are either too young or too old. You are expected to hate your skin, hate any changes, and hate any sign of ageing, even though ageing is an inevitable part of life. I have so many memories of women in my life telling me how lucky I have to have young skin and tearing themselves apart 😔. I don't want to feel that way, I want to feel neutral and be able to enjoy and live my life, free from the fear that my skin might not fit a certain ideal. Demonising ageing is one of the many ways the patriarchy keeps women in their place, the more wisdom and experience you gain, the less valuable and worthy you are. It divides women into categories and pushing them into living in fear of the passage of time. It pushes women to spend time, money, and energy agonising over their skin. Women fear ageing for good reason. Older women face economic and social discrimination. Women who don't wear makeup face economic and social consequences. Women who don't fit into the patriarchy's narrow ideals face discrimination and violence. Feeling neutral is a goal we can all hopefully aim for. #misogyny #ageism #feminism #feminist #smashthepatriarchy #feministaf #genderroles #agingdisgracefully #aging #30flirtyandthriving

One of my earliest baby feminist memories is being interrupted by my grandmother while playing and asked to go help with set up for dinner in the kitchen, when I pointed out that my older brother haven't been asked, just me and my sisters, I was told to stop being difficult. You better believe I dragged my brother into that kitchen so fast 😄. To his credit, he also realises how unfair that was and is raising his son different. The unequal nature of domestic labour gets even more pronounced during the festive season, as so many mothers and other women take on the burden of creating the perfect Christmas with little or no support. They feel the pressure to make everyone else's time magical but they deserve support and they deserve to rest too! The only way to break this pattern is to teach boys to get off their arse and help and to refuse to pander to men perfectly capable of taking on tasks themselves. Get your own mother a present yourself 🙄 #feministchristmas #genderroles #domesticlabor #genderinequality #herstory #feminism #feministnews #feministquotes #womensupportingwomen❤️ #feminism #feminist #intersectionalfeminism #intersectionalfeminist #16daysofactivism #feministaf #raisingboys #socialjusticewarrior #raisinggirls #childraising #christmasmagic #misogyny #christmasiscoming #equality #christmasquote #christmastips #smashthepatriarchy #christmasquotes #feministaf #socialjusticeeducation #toxicmasculinity #xmasiscoming #motherhood

⁣“I was working in a busy A&E, when a man came in who was caring for his brother with learning difficulties. The man with learning difficulties was in a terrible state, and clearly hadn't been cared for properly as his clothes were soiled and he had dried faeces on his legs. I asked the brother to step out so I could complete personal care for the man, but he refused stating, ‘He doesn't need privacy.’ I asked the man with learning difficulties if he was comfortable with his brother staying, and he said he was.⠀ I began to undress the man, and when I bent over to pick up a towel from the floor the brother said, ‘You're giving me ideas, bending over like that. I've always had a thing for nurses.’⠀ I told the man how inappropriate his comment was, but he still refused to leave the room. I continued with personal care, and although no further comments were made, I felt intimidated and frighted, and I could feel his eyes on me the whole time. I told a senior member of staff about the incident and they simply said, ‘Unfortunately its just one of those things.’⠀ It happened less than a year into being a qualified nurse.” - Becca ⠀ #FrontlineHarassment is a new photo series documenting the experiences of harassment essential workers routinely face. Over the past year, with all the focus being on key workers during the pandemic, I wanted to hear some of the stories from the frontline that rarely take centre stage. This photo was taken on #FaceTime #keyworkerseries #frontline #keyworkers #essentialworker #endharassment #placement #traineedr #doctorintraining #nhs #doctor

“As a postwoman, I get catcalled and shouted at by workmen most days of my working week. Some weeks it’s every single day. It got to the point at the beginning of this year where I was having to fight off panic attacks whenever I was delivering to houses having work done. I’d feel my gut twist as work vans past me, anticipating the shouts, leers and invasive comments about my body. Last week a middle age man was parked across the driveway of a house I was delivering to, he leaned out of his window and said, ‘Girl, you need to stop moving so fast, your body is making me sweat.’ I avoided the house for the rest of the week. I felt embarrassed, uncomfortable, and in light of the recent news regarding Sarah Everard and the outpouring of stories from women who’ve experienced harassment and violence at the hands of men, I now feel scared and unsafe. I smile and carry on walking, even though smiling at them is the last thing I want to do. If I don’t respond I get shouted at more, or laughed at, so smiling is just the easiest option. I’m tired of being treated like this- just for being a woman. Like my male colleagues I’m literally just trying to work, trying to pay my bills." -Sascha #FrontlineHarassment is a new photo series documenting the experiences key workers routinely face. Over the past year, with all the focus being on essential workers during the pandemic, I wanted to hear some of the stories from the frontline that rarely take centre stage. This photo was taken on #facetime #keyworker #frontline #essentialworker #nhs #post #postwoman #endharassment #royalmail #catcalling #endcatcalling #facetimeshoot

This morning I did an interview with @lbc radio about “the death of seduction” stemming from the ban of the song “Baby It’s Cold Outside”. Where I was repeatedly asked, how many times can a man ask a woman to stay over after her saying no. And the bottom line of the question being, can’t men seduce women anymore? . Firstly, how many times do women need to say no before they are listened to? And honestly, if a woman really wanted to stay the night, you wouldn’t have to ask her 5 times. . There is this myth that has been repeatedly told to us in films and music, which is if you ask a woman enough, eventually she will just give in and say yes. My question is this; How seductive is it really, if the woman is repeatedly saying no? 🤔 . - #consent .

Speaking about the column written by Jeremy Clarkson, Prince Harry said: “What he said was horrific, and it’s hurtful and cruel towards my wife, but it also encourages other people around the UK and around the world, men particularly, to think it’s acceptable to treat women that way. To use my stepmother’s words, there is a global pandemic of violence against women.” ⁠ ⁠ The Sun said sorry... but what for? A spokesperson for Harry and Meghan said the statement was a “PR stunt” and that The Sun hadn’t reached out to Meghan. The Sun mentioned the “strong response” to Clarkson’s column, but made no mention of the actual impact of what he called a “clumsy reference”. It’s difficult to take an apology as sincere when the body issuing it won’t say exactly what it’s for. ⁠ ⁠ How can we start to unpick the deeply woven culture of anger, hatred and violence towards women if we don’t acknowledge the impact of these seemingly less serious moments? How can we make women feel safer when we let things slide? ⁠ ⁠ Read more, from @ellencscott, via the link in our bio.⁠

"I have, in my time, attracted a fair few frenemies, both men and women. They have varied widely in terms of background and character, but the one common feature is that they made me feel being their friend was a precious and unparalleled gift – the equivalent of the toxic partner who tells you that you’ll “never find anyone who loves you like I do”. It takes years of recovery to realise you won’t, and that this is a good thing because the way they loved you was unhealthy and controlling and not a little narcissistic."⁠ ⁠ In an extract from her new book Friendaholic: Confessions Of A Friendship Addict, @elizabday muses on the frenemy. ⁠ ⁠ Link in bio to read.

“Running is a way for people to take control in a way they perhaps can’t with their love life and careers. You’re not relying on someone else, or something external. Many people watching this clip will think to themselves "well I would leave him if he spoke to me like that" But that is why love bombing is a key stage of the pattern of emotional abuse. Love bombing is characterised by excessive attention, admiration, and affection with the goal to make the recipient feel dependent and obligated to that person. It is a manipulative tactic. It makes you feel special, needed, loved, valuable, and worthy, which are all the components that contribute to and increase a person’s self-esteem. In the Love bomber stage, everything seems perfect. You have all the validation and affirmation you’ve ever wanted. But then, after the love bomber has gained your trust, the switch happens, and behaviour like this emerges. The conning, manipulation, and abuse begin. Like a switch, this person who once made you feel like so good starts to belittle, control, and devalue you. And because you had a taste of how it could be in the love bombing stage, you are more willing to give them leeway and make excuses. You think "well if I am just less annoying, he will return to the lovely man I first met." They don't return (except temporarily), it only gets worse. Victims of this behaviour will often feel very confused and mentally all over the place. This is by the perpetrator's design. It is never your fault. (This is part of my Married at First Sight series, for much more sign up at the Patreon link in the bio) -#lovebombing #marriedatfirstsight #britishtv #realitytv #smashthepatriarchy #emotionalabuse #healthyrelationships #mafs #marriedatfirstsightuk #mafsuk #redflags #redflag #feminist #feminism #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #redflagsinmen

There is typically an escalation in abusive behaviours as the abusive partner becomes comfortable with abuse, know they can push the boundaries and often as a considered response to increase or maintain control over the other person. Many people dismiss acts like punching a wall as "well I didn't hurt anyone" so it doesn't "count" or even "well I didn't hurt anyone" so it is a good action because they see it as releasing their anger without punching a person. Many people dismiss it as men just being out of control or even as a "healthy" expression of anger because "boys will be boys". If someone genuinely can't help themselves from smashing stuff when they are angry, they need anger management therapy. Punching a wall is violent and it is a huge red flag, one you should run from. Destroying your belongings shows a desire to hurt you. Domestic violence is born from small changes in already violent acts. Abusive words and threats escalate, smashing stuff escalates, pushing escalates, and punching escalates. Femicide doesn't happen out of nowhere. "Smashing things" is listed as a type of domestic violence by the National Domestic Violence Hotline for a reason. #controllingrelationships #maleviolence #redflagsindating #smashthepatriarchy #redflagsinmen #abusiverelationship #domesticabuse #redflags #redflag #feminist #feminism #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #misogyny #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #domesticabuseawareness #redflagsinmen #gaslightingawareness #controllingrelationship #toxicrelationships #healthyrelationship #domesticviolenceadvocate #feministmemes #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #emotionalabuse #gaslighting #domesticviolence #misogyny #domesticabusesupport #youdesrvebetter #relationshipadvice #boyswillbeheldaccountablefortheiractions #abusivebehaviour

In relationships, both partners should support the other to learn and grow, but too many men are entering adulthood and entering romantic relationships without the basic skills needed for successful healthy relationships. This fails men, and it fails the women who have to put in the labour, energy, and patience needed to make their relationship with this man that they love work. In times gone by, this dynamic wasn't challenged. Women were told not to expect much emotional support from their partners and to just be happy with that. After all, you didn't have much choice. But now we expect relationships full of love and connections, we deserve those relationships, and for that to be possible, the skills of emotional intelligence, communication, empathy, and listening are needed. Women who, from a young age, are expected to learn these skills, are more likely to enter into adult romantic relationships already equipped with them, men are not. But these skills are not inherent, they are can be learnt. Men are perfectly capable of learning them themselves and not putting all that emotional labour onto their current or future partners. Because love only goes so far, women won't be sticking around to grow a man anymore. We expect them to be fully grown. As someone who was in a relationship with a man 10 years senior in my early 20’s, much of this “case for marrying an older man” reads like a list of red flags.🚩 The 1st one that really hit home, was the describing of an other half not as a partner, but as “my mentor, lover, and in only certain contexts, my friend.” When my relationship ended, something I’d told myself throughout was that he was more of a mentor to me than a partner. The problem with this was, with a 10 year age, earnings and work experience gap, there was a huge power imbalance. Yet one of the most obvious things in this article is the security and romance the author writes about doesn’t come from an age gap, it comes from a wealth gap - which makes it read like a modern version of a 1950’s housewife manual for finding a “good husband”. I’m aware we are in the midst of a cultural pivot back to “traditional” values, anti-feminism, the stay-at-home-girlfriend and tradwives. (Did these ever really leave?) & I’m not going to sit here and tell people to not marry rich or work - women should be able to do what they want. However there is a more pressing case to be made for looking out for signs of coercive, emotional and financial control. According to @survivingeconomicabuse : 🔴1 in 6 women in the UK experience financial abuse in a current or former relationship. 🔴95% of women who experience abuse report experiencing economic abuse. 🔴More than half of women experiencing DA said they had no money so couldn’t leave. This is a grim reality for countless women & worth mentioning if we are having the “marrying rich” convo. “I live in an apartment whose rent he pays and that shapes the freedom with which I can ever be angry with him.” I’m sure there are many benefits to marrying rich- but at what cost? When the house of cards is built on youth, beauty and mentorship - what happens when we grow up, our bodies change, or we eventually want a career or financial freedom? I fear this article doesn’t make a case for marrying older, it makes a case for finding financial independence and a partner who doesn’t treat you like a pet...

More than half of working mothers have experienced some form of discrimination, either during their pregnancy, maternity leave or upon their return to the workplace, @pregnant_then_screwed found.⁠ ⁠ The charity, which aims to eradicate the motherhood penalty, teamed up with Women In Data to survey more than 24,000 parents, uncovering the workplace discrimination that women face after becoming mothers.⁠ ⁠ Read more at the link in our bio.

It’s expected that women have some sort of instinctive desire to have children and somehow also know how to take care of them, regardless of needs, wants, or experience due to maternal instinct. And while wanting to have children and take care of them is great, the idea that just because you’re a woman you should “instinctively” know what to do with them is unrealistic and adds a whole lot of unnecessary anxiety and stress. On the flip side, it is expected that men will be useless with all children including their own and that they won't be the primary caregiver, that why it's "Daddy daycare" and "I hope he will be OK left alone with the baby". It leads to men who exhibit any kind of child care skills being highly praised. Well done Paige for rejecting the mother role so many men put women into in relationships! 👏👏 The role of "mother" is forced on women who have immature, lazy and/or emotionally stunted male partners. Within femininity "motherly” characteristics are put on a pedestal: tolerance, gentleness, caring, nurturing, sensitivity, nurturance, deference. These can be wonderful qualities but not when they enable men to take advance of women. Mothers are always supposed to put everyone else first — they are not to be selfish or demanding or aggressive. Women in this role are responsible for doing all the emotional labour (and often domestic labour) in heterosexual relationships — constantly “working on” things like communication and connectivity. Reinforcing the idea that a “good” girlfriend or wife is one that constantly tries to “fix” a man is not only gross but harmful. It teaches women that it is their duty to not only accept male behaviour that is unacceptable but to take on responsibility for it, responsibility that should be on the man's shoulders. More and more women are unsure if they want children or sure that they don't and some people just can't get their heads around it. So many people just assume that all women are desperate for child because isn't that the whole point of women?! But it's more common for women to be unsure than men. A poll from 2013 found that more than 80 percent of men said they’d always wanted to be a father or at least thought they would be someday. Just 70 percent of women felt the same. Is it any wonder when women are asked to sacrifice so much to be mothers? Our health, our careers, our unpaid labour. Roe v Wade has been overturned. We are outraged and heartbroken for the women of America. The Supreme Court’s ruling is more than a life changing regression on reproductive rights, it threatens the foundations of equality; the autonomy women have to make decisions about our own bodies and lives. Abortion rights must be entrenched in law because abortion rights ARE human rights. And today’s ruling for women in the US is a harsh snapshot of what many women around the world fear, and of course which many must already endure. More on what it means - and what we can do - via the link in our bio. #roevwade #abortionrights

What does it mean to be "a wife"? Women are just as capable as men of internalising patriarchal ideas about women and their role in relationships. In our society, the meaning of and history of marriage is so deeply rooted in patriarchy and gender inequality, that when these women talk about being "a wife" they imagine it as a role that serves "a husband" through domestic and sexual labour, rather than as a partnership between two equals. The patriarchy tells women that they exist to serve others, that they must prove that they can do this (by being hot, by doing unpaid domestic labour, by being good at sex, even by getting an education) in order to be 'worthy' of marriage and 'worthy' of the role of wife. (This is the first of my Reels about the Netflix Reality dating show "The Ultimatum") Please see my Patreon for more on this topic and about other Reality TV shows! One the largest Tory donors, Frank Hester made racist, violent and misogynistic comments about Labour MP Dianne Abbot in 2019. While Hester claims they were “rude” - he completely failed to acknowledge the extreme, hateful misogynoir in these remarks. So what exactly is misogynoir? As you might know, Misogyny is an extreme form of sexism, defined as the hatred of women. Misogynoir is a term coined by the queer Black feminist Moya Bailey in 2010, referring to a specific form of sexism - rooted in racism. The term blends concepts that combine “misogyny” and the French word for black, “noir.” The concept was also notably introduced by Sojourner Truth, who spoke out about misogynoir before the term was coined in her “Ain’t I A Woman” speech at the Women’s Convention in 1851 There are PLENTY of ways that misogynoir manifests in real life - and sadly, these absolutely VILE and shameful comments from Tory donor Frank Hester are an example of exactly that... Sources: Northeastern University Blackburn Centre The BBC The Telegraph

After a nude photo posted by Mötley Crüe drummer Tommy Lee was allowed to remain on Instagram for hours, many of us are wondering why it seems like only women’s bodies get censored on the app?⁠ ⁠ “Photos of breastfeeding mothers with even the slightest sliver of areola showing are removed instantaneously. Images of Black curvy bodies are constantly shadow-banned or taken down. Testimonies of sexual harassment and abuse are suppressed and censored, and sex-positive pages are warned that their accounts are going to be deleted all the time. But a full-frontal image of a verified straight white man with over 1 million followers? Yep, totally fine. No community guidelines breached there. And do you know why? Because they were written by the very same men," says Eliza Hatch, creator of @cheerupluv.⁠ ⁠ Read the full story via the link in our bio.⁠

For most of us, our homes are our havens. A safe space away from the threat of coronavirus. But for thousands of women, being told to stay behind closed doors right now couldn’t be more terrifying. We spoke to leading domestic abuse charities @solacewomensaid, @womanstrust, Bede and @refugecharity about the women in danger during lockdown, and how we can help. Tap on the link in the bio to download our digital issue for free to read more. ⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ If you want to access support over the phone at any time, the freephone, 24-hour National Domestic Abuse Helpline is 0808 2000 247. If you are in immediate danger, call 999. If you want to help someone who is struggling, the #EveryDayAllyship is a new online platform by @unwomenuk which signposts services and advice to support women facing abuse during Covid-19 isolation.⁠⠀ ⁠Words: @lisajourno

Each year in Parliament, Jess Phillips MP reads out the names of women who have killed by men over the past 12 months. This year, it took more than five minutes to read out the 98 names (see my story for the full video). Jess Phillips has said she is “tired that women’s safety matters so much less” than small boats in parliament, why is it a near-empty chamber? The UN has said that UK’s strategies for tackling violence against women and girls fall short of the level of binding legislation and are not rooted in human rights language. Every three days, a woman is killed by a man in the UK, and one in four women experience domestic violence. Those of us who fight for change, who hear these names every year, are tired and sick of it getting worse due to austerity and lack of government action. Many of you might remember that I attended a MAFS event hosted by the show where, during the Q&A, I called out Brad's behaviour and asked them why they continued to put abusers on the show (I mention George from last season too). I was shut down with "they are maybe moving too fast." We saw it for what it was. One of my aims is to make the world a lot less comfortable for abusers, while also showing that they aren't "evil monsters", they are people we know. I want to give people the tools needed to call out this behaviour, to call it unacceptable. Many people, either due to their own experiences or knowledge, are able to identify emotional abuse when they see it. That doesn’t mean it is easy to escape abuse relationships or save your friends from abusive relationships or identify the abusers in your life, but it can be a tool in your arsenal. Some abusers are far more open (like Brad), others are much better at playing the "nice guy," but I want people to be able to see their friends being treat like Shona and understand the need for a girls' night where they ask her if she is OK and needs any support. To have a mate like Brad and to understand the need to tell him that you won't stand for his behaviour and explain why. People in relationships deserve basic respect. No one should think that belittling and manipulation is something that someone who loves you will do. Love bombing is a manipulative tactic designed to make the victim think later on that it will get better ("if I just change in the way he wants me to, he will love me again"). It won't get better, you deserve better, seek support to help you leave. ❤️ (This is part of my Married at First Sight series, for much more sign up at the Patreon link in the bio) -#lovebombing #marriedatfirstsight #britishtv #realitytv #smashthepatriarchy #emotionalabuse #healthyrelationships #mafs #marriedatfirstsightuk #mafsuk #redflags #redflag #feminist #feminism #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #redflagsinmen

Did you know the majority of incidents of harassment on public transport happen between 5-6pm during rush hour? This is an incredibly important piece of research that has just been published by the BBC, as it completely busts the myth that harassment happens when you are alone, or travelling in the middle of the night in an empty carriage. These are the kind of myths that often perpetuate victim blaming narratives and don’t lead us towards useful solutions to tackle the problem. We know that harassment can happen at any time, in any place of course , however it’s imperative that we dispel these misconceptions once and for all so we can create better systems of prevention and supporting survivors. Thanks BBC News for having me and my hot take on this new piece of research around the rise in reporting incidents of sexual harassment on public transport. 🙏 If you are travelling, and you witness an incident. Doing something is better than nothing, we need all commuters to engage and become active bystanders to we can tackle this problem together once and for all ❤️ #endharassment #sexualharassment #publictransport #bbcnews

!!️MAKE BYSTANDER INTERVENTION EDUCATION MANDATORY!!️ There needs to be a mass education program of bystander intervention to people of all ages and backgrounds in this country and across the world . I am absolutely horrified and appalled that a woman could be r*ped in broad daylight, in rush hour, in front of witnesses on the tube. Disgusted doesn’t even cover how I feel right now. We already know that there is a HUGE lack of bystander intervention when it comes to sexual harassment and assault in public. But how, HOW could this happen ? How is there still no CCTV inside tube carriages - and did any is try to stop it? There’s no doubt it would have been an absolutely terrifying ordeal for the French national and their child to witness. But surely, surely something could have been done to stop this happening? I do not want to put blame on the bystander. The blame lies with the perpetrator alone - however there are systems in play that regularly contribute to harm against women and marginalised genders. Why wasn’t this man apprehended after exposing himself, m*sturbating and chasing two women earlier that same morning? Why is there STILL no CCTV inside tube carriages and plenty of other forms of public transport? Why doesn’t bystander intervention seem to be COMMON KNOWLEDGE or widely practiced by anyone ever?? Sadly I think we all know the answers to all of these questions, but that still doesn’t make it right. When it comes to some ways of intervening, you might hear people refer to the 5 D’s. These are known as: Direct Delegate Delay Distract Document I am going to do a follow up post specifically on this to go into more details. I am heartbroken for the poor woman who went through this. Sending love, solidarity and so much support. This should never have happened. Also sending support to the women who were harassed and assaulted by the same man, and anyone else affected by this awful awful incident. 💔 If you are reading this and need to access support/resources - please do so via the link in my bio.

In today's episode of #NobodyToldMe, we're joined by beauty influencer and creator and host of the podcast 'What would the auntie say?', @anchal. Anchal is a British-Indian make-up artist, who has built up a large online community through her brilliant digital make-up tutorials and honest reviews. After leaving University with a degree in special effects make-up seven years ago, she spotted, in her words, what little visibility and representation brown girls had in the online beauty world, and subsequently began producing her own content - quickly gaining traction with an audience who had previously been neglected. So far in the first series, she's covered everything from mental health and marriage to anti-blackness and colourism. She believes strongly that the only way to tackle outdated and judgemental views is for younger generations to feel they have the tools to educate and challenge the older generations. But one of the big issues she tackles is navigating life as a single woman at an age when she is expected to be married. Click on the link in our bio for Ancal's story in her own words. ⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ *This episode is sponsored by @cliniqueuk

When you love someone you know intimate details about their life, you know their trauma and their experiences, maybe better than anyone else in their life. This might mean that if they treat you in a disrespectful, hurtful and/or abusive way, you are have the excuse at the tip of your tongue: "what he did was wrong but (insert difficult life experience here)." Being a supportive, kind and empathy person doesn't mean anyone gets to disrespect you. You can support someone to heal their trauma without staying in a situation that is harmful to you. You can be understanding of what someone has been through in their life without excusing their current harmful actions. You can love someone still have boundaries and standards about how they treat you. Every adult is responsible for their own harmful actions, whatever has happened in their past. Every adult is responsible for their own healing, you can't force someone to change, no matter how much you love them. Sometimes you have to walk away and that's ok #genderbasedviolence #intersectionalfeminism #smashthepatriarchy #victimblaming #feministaf #socialjusticeeducation #socialjusticeeducation #healthyrelationship #toxicmasculinity #intersectionalfeminist #healthyrelationshipsmatter #feministquotes #notallmen #feminist #feminism #coercivecontrol #healthyrelationshipsmatter #rapeculture #misogyny #feminismisforeverybody #rapecultureisreal #domesticviolenceawareness #domesticabuseawareness #domesticabuseadvocate #genderedviolence #toxicrelationships #domesticabuse #healthyrelationshipeducation #domesticviolenceprevention #domesticabusesupport

As a woman feminist on the Internet, I get an awful lot of online abuse along a similar line: "You are just bitter and alone," "You will die alone," "You are just mad that no man will ever love you," 🥱 These misogynists want to punish feminists and the most severe punishment they can think of is the withdrawal of their penis and "love." This misogynist myth about feminists has a long history rooted in anti suffragette propaganda and the witch trials. They can't ever imagine loving a woman who advocates for her own and other women's humanity and liberty, they can only imagine a relationships based on control and subjugation, so they can't wrap their head around feminists having lives full of love and friendship, sometimes with men, sometimes with other women, always with each other. I don't make my fiancée the centre of my social media because he isn't what this space is about (I also.want to protect him tbh), I love him, and I love our relationship. It isn't what makes me valuable as a person, it isn't the reason my voice matters. Women are told their entire lives that they need to be "chosen" by a man, screw that. You don't need to be "chosen", you need real relationships based on human connection and respect. Misogynists online don't care about reality or getting to know me as a person, they just want to imagine that I am alone and miserable (I am not) and scare other women into accepting their own oppression (it's not working). #onlineabuse #feminism #womensupportingwomen❤️ #feminism #feminist #femaleempowermentquotes #misogyny #feministaf #feministquotes #womensrights #smashthepatriarchy #feministaf #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #feministmemes #feminismisforeverybody #feministquotes

“This ad was opposite my place of work. I had to stare at it out of the window. A colleague and I went out and added the graffiti. You can see that there are two handwritings! It was a way of taking over the poster. [...] By writing angry but humorous graffiti, we were also making the point that ad agencies don’t have the monopoly on wit.” - Jill Posener, London, 1979 🚨🚗 Have you ever heard of “culture jamming”? Maybe, maybe not - but you might have heard of the Guerrilla Girls - an anonymous feminist collective of women artists formed in 1980’s in New York, who challenged discrimination in the art world. They engaged in a practice known as culture jamming, which was a set of tactics aimed at disrupting the status quo, uprooting dominant order and turning it on its head. Jill Posener is a British feminist photographer, known for her exploration of lesbian identity, who played a key role in culture jamming in the UK, with her signature edge of wit and sarcasm. Posener’s work is one of many feminist pieces being displayed at a new exhibition at the @tate @tatebritainlondon ,”Women In Revolt! Art and Activism in the UK 1970-1990”, opening next week from 8th Nov 2023 – 7th April 2024. If you want a re-education in feminist art or need a spot for a cute first date, this exhibition is the place for you!! 😤💘💪

Whether she’s campaigning for ending violence against women or defending herself and her family from shaming, Oscar winner and Hollywood icon #HalleBerry has long been an inspiration to many. And her latest social media interaction has prompted widespread praise – and delivered a masterclass in not allowing anyone to dampen your shine.⁠ ⁠ On Saturday, Berry, 56, shared an empowering photo of herself drinking wine in the nude on a balcony to Instagram. The post was immediately met with praise from fans who congratulated her on celebrating her body. But, unfortunately, not all on the internet had positive feedback. Berry was also subjected to body shaming and ageism by those who criticised her for sharing the image.⁠ ⁠ Link in bio to read how she handled it.

Spain has become the first European country to offer paid menstrual leave, in a progressive move by the government to guarantee better menstrual health.⁠ ⁠ In a statement on Thursday, the Spanish Congress said the new bill creates the possibility for women to call in sick “in case of incapacitating menstruation.”⁠ ⁠ According to Politico, it was adopted by 185 votes against 154, with three abstentions. The bill was backed by an expansive left-wing coalition including the Socialist Party, far-left Podemos and two pro-Catalan independence parties. The conservative Popular Party and far-right Vox voted against the measure.⁠ ⁠ On the same day, Spanish Congress also gave final approval to laws which expanded abortion and transgender rights for teenagers.⁠ ⁠ 👏❤️⁠ ⁠ More on the news at the link in our bio.

Artemisia Gentileschi is one of the most celebrated female painter of the 17th century and she was something so rare that it seems impossible: A 17th century female artist who was able to use her art fight back against the male violence that dominated the world she lived in. To express her rage at the oppression she experienced. At 18, she was raped by her artist mentor, she publicly accused him at a time when that alone was rare. During the trial she was tortured in the court room with thumb screws. Her rapist was set free, not because he was proven innocent but because he was protected by the Pope. And so she painted her pain and painted her imagined revenge in the form of Judith Slaying Holofernes (a tale from the Old Testament). While her male contemporaries were painting adoring Madonna or a naked nymphs, her painting and her skill you can really feel. I could have looked at it all day. Yet it was in a room as just an add on to the Caravaggio collection and nothing in the giftshop carried its image. I felt like the Uffizi Gallery in Florence doesn't really value it and what it stands for as much as they should. #artemisiagentileschi #uffizigallery #femalerage #rapeculture #femaleartist #arthistory #herstory #womenshistory #historylovers #womeninhistory #womensupportingwomen❤️ #womeninart #intersectionalfeminism #internationalwomensday #intersectionalfeminist #womenshistorymonth #feministquotes #feminist #feminism #femaleempowerment #womensrights #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #empoweringwomen #feministaf #womensupportingwomen❤️ #historylovers #girlpower💪 #historymeme

Nearly 50% of Brits think gender equality has gone too far!!️ A new study from Kings College has revealed that nearly 1 in 2 Brits think that when it comes to giving women equal rights with men, things have gone far enough, and that we have gone so far in promoting women’s equality, men are now being discriminated against.🫠 Shockingly, this has gone up from 38% who said the same last year, and a 29% in 2019. This figure feels like an especially hard pill to swallow when in this country, 2 women are killed by their partners, 10,000 women are sexually assaulted, and 2,000 women are raped, every week. Don’t let anyone EVER tell you that the people who harass or assault you in public (or anywhere for that matter) are paying you a compliment, or that it’s a joke or banter. Perpetrators leave the with house intent to cause harm, or see an opportunity and take it. It’s abuse of power, and nothing more. This is why women and marginalised folk don’t feel safe. Yesterday was the 3 year anniversary of the day serving officer Wayne Couzens abused his police powers, abducted, raped and murdered Sarah Everard. It is hard to fathom how the horror of what happened to Sarah could get any worse, but since Lady Elish Angiolini’s inquiry published last week, it appears the police had plenty of opportunities to stop Couzens from offending, yet the harrowing fact of the matter remains that they didn’t, time and time again. The true magnitude of failures in vetting and policing have come to light, and it lays bare what we already knew: that the police didn’t take sexual harassment seriously enough. Couzens was a repeat sex offender before he ever crossed paths with Sarah Everard, including nine indecent exposure allegations, but somehow managed to evade any consequences and kept working as a police officer. Indecent exposure or “flashing” can sometimes be brushed off as a “joke”, “not that serious” - or just “some weirdo”, and is rarely dealt with or acknowledged with the gravitas and seriousness it warrants. When society, authorities, people in positions of power and privilege ignore and dismiss the “small stuff” - it sends a message that that kind of behaviour is okay, which allows for more serious forms of violence to escalate unchallenged. This is also known as the Pyramid of Sexual Violence, and is precisely why I have spent the past 7 years advocating around the awareness and combatting of everyday harassment and assault. When we ignore sexual harassment, that includes indecent exposure - we ignore misogyny, we ignore attitudes of sexism, we ignore women girls and marginalised genders feelings, safety and security. We also ignore a brewing problem of misogyny being left unchecked to evolve into sexual violence. The police had many opportunities to stop Couzens, but they turned a blind eye. Let this be the last time we have to remind the police that ALL forms of sexual harassment are completely unacceptable and should never ever be tolerated, and - I can’t believe I even have to say this sentence - especially by actual POLICE officers. #badapple #rottentothecore #saraheverard

Many of us were lucky enough to be raised in households where we were raised to see ourselves as equal to our brothers or other boys in our lives. This is obviously important and powerful, but it gives you as a little girl a false expectation of the world. That it is one where you will be treated equally. That you will be a human being first and foremost. The dawning realision that this isn't the case no one prepares you for: when older men start treating you as a sex object, when teachers make sexist comments, when you enter the workplace and you are overlooked and belittled, when you start dating and are treated badly. It is shocking, it should be shocking. Every generation of girls has had to face this. Each generation has fought to make the world better for the next. We pass on the torch, there is still far to go. #herstory #feminism #growingupagirl #womensupportingwomen❤️ #genderroles #raisinggirls #feminism #feminist #femaleempowermentquotes #misogyny #feministaf #beingawoman #feminism #feminist #misogyny #feministquotes #womensrights #smashthepatriarchy #feministaf #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #feministmemes #feminismquotes #feminismisforeverybody #feministquotes

When are we going to get past this????🚨NEWSFLASH 🚨- You can complain, make a fuss and be as loud as you goddamn please about not wanting to be sexually harassed or assaulted and also be a STRONG and EMPOWERED individual. ⠀ Just because women and marginalised genders are finally calling out the sexual misconduct which we have been forced to accept as normal in society DOESN’T mean that we are “disempowered victims”. ⠀ Do you know how much strength it takes to report your harasser? One of the most eye opening things about the Jonah Hill texts has been the polarising reactions from men and women. (Not all men not all women bla bla - I’m binary for the sake of the point) These texts have triggered a mass outpouring of women sharing their stories of experiencing controlling and abusive behaviour, because that’s exactly what these texts are - controlling and coercive, masked as setting “boundaries.” But what’s depressing, has been the amount of men coming to Jonah’s defence, rather than listening to the shared and lived experiences of women. Men have been saying, “he’s setting a boundary” or “you don’t know what abuse is” - which goes to show that ALOT of men still don’t know what boundaries OR what abusive behaviour looks like. Now this gets all the more complicated with the (predominantly good) wider access and destigmatisation of men accessing therapy, which on the whole is a *great* thing. What’s NOT so great, is the weaponisation of so called “therapy speak” when it gets to setting boundaries and the way we behave in romantic relationships. Let me make one thing clear: boundaries are things that you impose on yourself, they aren’t things you can impose on, or control in others. What’s also clear is the misunderstanding of how abuse and coercive control in relationships starts. It rarely starts with physical violence, but it almost always begins with limiting and controlling the other persons freedom and asserting fear and domination. This can then escalate into more controlling behaviour, and create an atmosphere of constant fear, which can and often does result in abusive and sometimes violent acts. Nearly every woman will know the feeling of walking on eggshells, or adjusting their behaviour in some way to appease a man. Whether that’s a partner, a boss, even a parent. We have been making ourselves smaller and more malleable for men for centuries, but we have also learnt that we don’t deserve to be treated like objects, playthings or pets anymore. We know what the warning signs look like, and we have shouted from the top of our lungs to warn others. It’s clear that some men just still aren’t listening. #jonahhill

Have said it once but will say it again, there is NO such thing as a perfect victim!!! There is NO such thing as a perfect way to respond to rape, assault, harassment or abuse!!! Most victims don’t even REALISE they have been assaulted or abused, sometimes until a significant amount of time has passed. Hell, there are COUNTLESS moments I could reflect on of personal experiences and situations I’ve been in where I’ve looked back and only realised it was wrong 10 YEARS LATER. And I know for a fact that I am far from alone in that experience. There is a commonly held perception that women and minorities have to be CONSTANTLY crying or showing distress and the appropriate emotions after they speak up about harassment or assault, and then they can’t break character for the rest of their lives. You either have to be a crying, distraught mess and make that your entire personality for the rest of your life or for any public appearance, or you’re a lying slut who was “asking for it” and just “playing the victim.” This narrative is currently playing out as we speak. Whether you are rape survivor or a World Cup winning athlete - there is NO correct way to “play the victim” - because the perfect victim doesn’t exist. 🙅‍♀️🙅‍♀️🙅‍♀️ #nosuchthingasaperfectvictim #nosuchthing #mythbust #bustingmyths #perfectvictim #mythbusting #believesurvivors #believevictims #believewomen #metoo

Consent is about communication, it should be freely given and enthusiastic. Enthusiastic consent can look like this: Asking permission before you change the type or degree of sexual activity with phrases like “Is this OK?” Confirming that there is reciprocal interest before initiating any physical touch. Letting your partner know that you can stop at any time. Periodically checking in with your partner, such as asking “Is this still okay?” Providing positive feedback when you’re comfortable with an activity. Explicitly agreeing to certain activities, either by saying “yes” or another affirmative statement, like “I’m open to trying.” Using physical cues to let the other person know you’re comfortable taking things to the next level (Source: RAINN) (This is part of my Love Island series, for much more, including daily analysis, check out my Patreon link in the bio) #loveisland #loveislanduk #loveislandreactions #loveisland #loveisland2023 #loveislandmeme #loveislandbants #loveislandcontestants #feminist #feminism #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #britishtv #realitytv #loveislandcast #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #datinglife #datingtips #dating101 #healthyrelationship #consentmatters #consentculture #consenteducation #rapeculture #consentmatters #consentissexy #consentismandatory #feminismisforeverybody #bodyautonomy #consent #intersectionalfeminism #intersectionalfeminist #feminist #feminism #realitytv

Giving children an option of a hug, high five or a fist bump gives them a choice, it empowers them and teaches them that their body autonomy and consent matters. We often talk about it content and boundaries in the context of romantic relationships situations, but it’s a skill we can use in any relationship. Helping our kids learn to assert their personal boundaries and respect those of others helps to lay the foundation for creating healthy romantic and sexual relationships when they’re older. Starting consent lessons early will help kids define boundaries and express themselves in their relationships now and for the rest of their lives. (This is a clip from Love is Blind, I have been analysing this season for my Patreon subscribers, learn more at the link in my bio!) #consentmatters #consentculture #consenteducation #rapeculture #consentmatters #consentissexy #consentismandatory #raisingboys #raisinggirls #empoweringkids #feminismisforeverybody #empoweringchildren #teachingkids #bodyautonomy #consent #intersectionalfeminism #intersectionalfeminist #teachingchildren #feministquotes #feminist #feminism #realitytv #loveisblind4 #loveisblind #loveisblindnetflix #loveisblindmemes #loveisblindseason4

🌹💘How to shut down the worst seduction technique ever invented!!💘🌹 Happy valentine’s everyone! Without further ado, here are some great comebacks to negging... But quickly -What’s negging you ask? Negging is a form of emotional manipulation, in the form of a backhanded compliment , which is used to undermine /diminish confidence of the person it’s directed at in the belief that it will make them more receptive to your advances. The term was coined and prescribed by pickup artists, and popularised by the book “rules of the game” - which I’m not going to give any more air time to - But that’s the history! (Read Laura Bates ‘men who hate women’ for more info) Negging can be as simple and subtle as making a backhanded compliment, such as “aren’t you beautiful? I would never have the courage to wear my hair like that.” The (misguided) intention is that the put down will make you more vulnerable and wanting to seek the approval of the (usually cis straight man) negging you. And somehow straight men think this makes us want to sleep with them?!? But this isn’t just something that happens with strangers in bars or on the street, this kind of emotional manipulation - ie. Abuse, can happen in relationships too. And it’s something to look out for! Anyway here are just some of my favourite comebacks: “Wow, what an interesting thing to say out loud” “Can you explain that? I don’t really get it” Just a plain “Thank you” with a nice big sarcastic smile “Sorry can you repeat that a bit louder, I didn’t quite catch it” Any of these responses will immediately undermine their undermining. Let’s firmly leave this manipulative tactic in the bin, it‘a not hot, cute or sexy and it makes anyone who uses it look like an abusive predator. Thanks for watching & please share! #happyvalentinesday #valentines #valentine #happyvalentine

Everyday is a great day to be an active bystander!! Today I want to talk about bystander intervention and share a post illustrated by @hellomynameiswednesday - based on a video from Collective Action For Safe Spaces. When we talk about bystander intervention, we often think of the most extreme version of this - something like a citizens arrest. But it doesn’t have to always be that confrontational, in fact there are many ways you can show up for and advocate for a person who is being harassed. When it comes to some of these ways, you might hear people refer to the 5 D’s. Those are known as: Direct Delegate Delay Distract Document While some of the ones illustrated in this post are slightly different, the majority of the messaging is the same. However - I would like to caveat that I probably wouldn’t engage or encourage the 3rd option if you are a woman or marginalised person, this is probably something in my opinion, that only a person who holds a certain amount of privilege and has done an extensive risk assessment could get away with - even then it’s definitely most risky option! I’d be interested to hear others thoughts on this below. These directions are supposed to show you options for how you can engage, sometimes it’s as little as asking someone if they are okay. Remember, when doing so please be safe and consider the safety of others around you. However doing something, is better than doing nothing. #bystanderintervention #activebystander

When you tell people you’re getting divorced at 31, the questions come thick and fast. “Why did you go through with it? Did something awful happen? Was he emotionally abusive? Did you meet someone else?” People want to pinpoint exactly what went wrong, maybe so they can scan their own horizons for warning signs. But the truth is, my husband wasn’t awful, and neither was my relationship. It just wasn’t enough. Saying that out loud was like coming up for air.⁠ ⁠ In our latest issue, content creator and campaigner @sashapallari tells Stylist why getting divorced is the bravest thing she’s ever done. Read more in our magazine - link in our bio to read the digital version. ⁠

When Anna* was 33, she found out that her husband of two years was cheating on her. At first, the reason behind the breakdown of her marriage made her feel ashamed, but as divorce proceedings got underway, that shame gave way to anger. She was determined that people should know exactly what had happened. “I told all and sundry what type of person he is,” she says. “He was an arse and the world should know what he did.”⁠ ⁠ Anna’s unapologetically combative approach stands in stark opposition to the picture of divorce that has often been painted – by celebrities and non-famous folk alike – over the last decade. Throughout the 2010s and into the 2020s, there has been a pervasive social expectation that, if couples can’t do til death do us part, they should at the very least end things amicably. ⁠ ⁠ In an age of conscious uncoupling, a messy divorce can be frowned upon but what if there’s something to be gained from releasing your rage? Stylist meets the women revelling in their breakup fury – link in bio.

2023 was a big year for women in film, but you wouldn’t think so by taking a glance at some of Hollywood’s biggest awards shortlists. ⁠ ⁠ Sofia Coppola gave us a glimpse into the world of Priscilla Presley in Priscilla, Emerald Fennell returned to our screens with the popular but divisive Saltburn, Celine Song made her directorial debut with Past Lives and we haven’t even mentioned the behemoth that was Greta Gerwig’s Barbie.⁠ ⁠ However, as awards season rolls on, female directors continue to be snubbed. And today, arguably the biggest and most respected awards ceremony in Hollywood unveiled its nominations for 2024, and again, one woman is featured in the best director shortlist, writes @shahedezaydi.⁠ ⁠ Read more at the link in our bio.

A new study by Young Women’s Trust has revealed that gender-based discrimination in the workplace is on the rise.⁠ ⁠ The charity’s annual survey of 4,000 women aged 18-30 found that 50% have experienced discrimination at work, a jump from 42% last year. Worse still, 25% are suffering in silence, feeling unable to challenge the sexist comments, dismissive behaviour and salary inequality they’re facing day in, day out. ⁠ ⁠ Read more at the link in our bio.

For female surgeons, sexual assault is distressingly routine. As a report published in the British Journal Of Surgery (BJS) recently showed, almost one in three of those working in the NHS has been sexually assaulted in the past five years, including 11 instances of rape. Nearly 90% of those surveyed said they had witnessed sexual misconduct; over a third had been on the receiving end of sexual ‘banter’, and 29% had experienced unwanted physical advances.⁠ ⁠ Revealing these grim statistics has been called surgery’s #MeToo moment. Stylist speaks to female surgeons about their experiences, and how important it is for things to change. Head to the link in bio to read. ⁠ ⁠ Content note: this article contains references to sexual assault that readers may find upsetting.

Do you remember when we told women to "fight sexism in the workplace with power poses"? That TED talk has thankfully had its moment, but there are still variations on this that get repeated, girlboss tips telling women to not say "just", to take ! out of their emails, to dress in a certain way, or speak a certain way. They are told to speak up and learn in! These tips claim to give women confidence and help them progess in their careers, and maybe for some individual women, they will be helpful. But, these tips are more likely to be at best useless and, at worst harmful. Research shows that women who are seen as too assertive or not assertive enough are punished in the workplace. Women have to trend a fine line between the two, an impossible task. Because women changing the behaviour can't fix an inequal system. Research shows that women are just as likely as men to ask for higher salaries, and men and women are equally likely to report avoiding negotiations if they feared it would hurt their relationship with their boss. But women are less like to get those raises when they ask. Why do we think that is? Devaluing "feminine" traits like being friendly, speaking softly, or standing in a particular way isn't helpful in the long run. Blaming women's lack of confidence or lack of assertiveness on why they aren't in leadership is victim blaming. Individual women are up against systemic inequality and misogyny. That is why there aren't enough women in leadership positions; that is why women are underpaid and overlooked. The only solution is a reimaging of power and leadership as a position for any gender and where feminine behaviours are seen as just as valuable as masculine ones, think Jacinda Ardern. Fix the system, not the women. #bossbabe👑 #bossbabemindset #bossbabequotes #girlbosslife #girlbossmindset #girlbosslifestyle #femalehustler #girlbossquotes #girlbossinspiration #feminismisforeverybody #powerpose #misogyny #womensmonth #womenshistorymonth #powerfulwomen #equalityintheworkplace #workplaceequality #femaleleadership

!!️ IMPORTANT!!️ Sexual harassment has a *severe* impact on women and marginalised genders mental health. It causes anxiety, depression, trauma, and dictates how we make hundreds of tiny decisions throughout the entire day. It impacts *every* part of our lives, and it makes those tiny -what should be mundane - decisions feel HUGE. But when the thing causing this anxiety is your boss? Not only that, but someone you live in a close proximity too? And your complaints or concerns are being ignored? I can’t imagine how destructive and isolating the impact of that would have been. The harassment Jaysley Beck endured from her army boss should not under *any* circumstances be downplayed as a factor in what happened to her. And nor should the accountability of the army - these things do not happen in a vacuum. They happen because some men can and will abuse their positions of power. They happen because of patriarchy. They happen because of misogyny going unchecked, ignored and unchallenged. They happen because they have been allowed to happen. And what about women? Well, women have been forced and socialised to make sure men don’t feel rejected. To keep men happy. Not wound their fragile egos. Constantly appease and be polite as to not appear rude, for fear of repercussions. So we don’t get treated aggressively. So we don’t upset them. So we don’t get called frigid. So we don’t make a scene or cause a fuss. So we don’t get killed. Because an insecure man with a wounded ego can be a very dangerous thing. Because we have been told that we are responsible for for men’s feelings and actions. It’s fucking exhausting. And it’s fucking unfair. Harassment ruins lives. It ruins opportunities for women and marginalised groups. It makes your world smaller. It has real life consequences, and It’s fundamentally a symptom and an aggravating factor of gender inequality. We will never be equal until we feel safe. RIP Jaysley. Sending so much support to your family and friends ❤️‍🩹 This shouldn’t have happened.

Did you know almost 2/3 women have been sexually harassed at work? Well...if you follow this page, you’re probably not that surprised. A new study from the Trades Union Congress has revealed that 2/3 women experience harassment, bullying or verbal abuse at work & that most victims do not report for fear of not being believed, or wanting to damage future career prospects or work relationships. I’m sorry...#MeToo has gone too far WHO? WHAT?? Just no! We have always needed more than just a hashtag or infographic to create meaningful actionable change, and make women and marginalised folk feel safer in public spaces - but these statistics are so depressing! It’s been 5 years since MeToo, and we are still living in a time where women are scared to speak out about being harassed for fear of losing their jobs. Has much progress really been made? Perhaps the awareness around MeToo has meant more people can recognise acts of harassment for what they are, but has the culture on a whole changed enough? If looking at the business sector in this country is anything to go by, the recent allegations against the CBI really say it all. I had a look into the prevalence of workplace harassment when doing my photo series #frontlineharassment - speaking to key workers during the time of the pandemic about their experiences being harassed at work. This was at a time where we were all clapping for carers & NHS workers, when at the same government was giving out pitiful pay rises. It sparked a huge conversation around workplace safety, harassment claims and how little women are appreciated in key worker roles. We know it’s not just frontline workers who experience daily harassment, it’s everyone else apparently too. (or as the survey points out - 62% of women age 25-34) These figures are unacceptable in a modern functioning society. Women and people of marginalised genders will never truly be equal to men if we are constantly being tormented in our place of work, alongside all the other forms of discrimination we already face. How many more years is it going to take???? #safespace #workplaceharassment #endharassment #endworkplaceabuse #endabuse #endworkplacebullying

I find it interesting when cis men talk about wanting large families, especially single men. They very rarely acknowledge that they are talking about a woman they haven't even met yet risking her life and her health to achieve this dream of his. Men who have this dream are very unlikely to take on the burden of labour of a large family after the birth either. Over the past half-century, fathers in America nearly tripled their child care time from 2.5 hours per week in 1965 to seven hours per week in 2011. But, over this period, women’s parenting time too has increased – from 10 hours per week in 1965 to 14 hours per week in 2011. This pattern repeats in the UK. When considering time spent in child care plus time spent in housework and working for pay, the birth of a baby increased mothers’ total workload by 21 hours per week. In contrast, fathers’ total workload increased by only 12.5 hours per week. This represents a 70 percent greater increase in workload for women compared to men. These differences cannot be explained away by differences in paid work hours or breastfeeding With this in mind a man wanting a large family isn't the same as a woman wanting one.
